contentrichtext.text: {{Starbox begin | name = [http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-id?Ident=OGLE-TR%20122 OGLE-TR-122] }} {{Starbox image | image = [[File:1e8m comparison Saturn Jupiter OGLE-TR-122b with Uranus Neptune Sirius B Earth Venus no transparency.png|250px]] | caption = The [[Earth]]-[[Moon]] orbit, [[Saturn]], [[OGLE-TR-122b]], [[Jupiter]], and [[1 E7 m|other objects]], to scale. }} {{Starbox observe | epoch = [[J2000.0]] ([[International Celestial Reference System|ICRS]]) | constell= [[Carina (constellation)|Carina]] | ra = {{RA|11|06|51.99}}<ref name="aa">[http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2003AcA....53..133U The Optical Gravitational Lensing Experiment. Additional Planetary and Low-Luminosity Object Transits from the OGLE 2001 and 2002 Observational Campaigns], A. Udalski, G. Pietrzynski, M. Szymanski, M. Kubiak, K. Zebrun, I. Soszynski, O. Szewczyk, and L. Wyrzykowski, ''Acta Astronomica'' '''53''' (June 2003), pp. 133–149.</ref> | dec = {{DEC|-60|51|45.7}}<ref name="aa" /> }} |- ! style="background-color: #FFFFC0;" colspan="2" | Characteristics |- | '''[[Stellar classification|Spectral type]]'''<sup> </sup> <br /> | ? (primary)/M (b)<ref name="xit" /> |- style="vertical-align: top;" | '''[[Apparent magnitude]]'''<sup> </sup> <br /> '''(infrared, I band)''' | 15.61 (system)<ref name="aa" /> |- style="vertical-align: top;" | '''[[Variable star|Variable type]]''' | [[Eclipsing binary]] |- ! style="background-color: #FFFFC0;" colspan="2" | [[Binary star|Binary orbit]] |- style="vertical-align: top;" | '''[[Orbital period|Period]] <small>(P)</small>''' | 7.269<ref name="xit">[http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2005A&A...433L..21P A planet-sized transiting star around OGLE-TR-122. Accurate mass and radius near the hydrogen-burning limit], F. Pont, C. H. F. Melo, F. Bouchy, S. Udry, D. Queloz, M. Mayor, and N. C. Santos, ''Astronomy and Astrophysics'' '''433''', #2 (April 11, 2005), pp. L21–L24.</ref> [[day]]s |- style="vertical-align: top;" | '''[[Eccentricity (orbit)|Eccentricity]] <small>(e)</small>''' | 0.205 |- style="vertical-align: top;" | '''[[Inclination]] <small>(i)</small>''' | 88–90° {{Starbox detail | mass = 1.0 (primary) / 0.09 (b) | radius = 1.1 (primary) / 0.12 (b) | temperature = 5,700 (primary) }} {{Starbox end}} '''OGLE-TR-122''' is a [[binary star|binary]] [[stellar system]] containing one of the smallest [[main-sequence]] [[star]]s whose [[radius]] has been measured. It was discovered when the [[Optical Gravitational Lensing Experiment]] (OGLE) survey observed the smaller star eclipsing the larger primary. The orbital period is approximately 7.3 days. The system's primary is thought to resemble the [[Sun]].<ref name="xit" /> The smaller star, '''OGLE-TR-122B''', is estimated to have a [[radius]] around 0.12 [[solar radii]], or around 20% larger than [[Jupiter]]'s, and a [[mass]] of around 0.1 [[solar mass]]es, or approximately 100 times Jupiter's. This makes its average [[density]] approximately 50 times the Sun's<ref name="xit" /><ref>[http://www.space.com/scienceastronomy/050303_star_small.html Newfound Star Smaller than Some Planets], Robert Roy Britt, space.com, accessed on line May 16, 2007.</ref> or over 80 times the density of [[water]]. OGLE-TR-122b's mass is close to the lowest possible mass, estimated to be around 0.07 or 0.08 solar masses, for a [[hydrogen]]-fusing star.<ref>[http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2000ARA&A..38..337C Theory of Low-Mass Stars and Substellar Objects], Gilles Chabrier and Isabelle Baraffe, ''Annual Review of Astronomy and Astrophysics'' '''38''' (2000), pp. 337–377.</ref> The observed transit provides the first direct evidence for a star with a radius comparable to Jupiter's.<ref name="xit" /> ==See also== * [[OGLE-TR-123]] == References == {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ogle-Tr-122}} [[Category:Carina (constellation)]] [[Category:Eclipsing binaries]]
